title: Artist calls for world stewardship
text:
Artist calls for world stewardship Oct 02, 2015 "Driftwood" is a work of sculpted paper by Marnie Sinclair. 
Rockland — Bronze sculpture, oil paintings, shaped paper, wire sculptures, mixed media with lens gels and wood — all made by the hands of artist Marnie Sinclair of Damariscotta — will go on view Sunday, Oct. 11, in the Sanctuary Gallery of Rockland Congregational Church, 180 Limerock St. The show of varied works will open with an 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. reception to meet the artist. 
Nature has always inspired Sinclair's art, and she considers herself an environmental activist. Her mixed media mobiles depict pollution of air, ice and waters; her oils of endangered animals' eyes reveal the cause of their demise in the center of each pupil. 
“My art often reflects my concern about climate change and how we are living in a non-sustainable way that impacts all life on the planet,” she said. 
A multi-faceted artist, she works with wire, bronze and resin to create a wide assembly of animals, wild or domesticated. When she operated her own Outside in Designs business she designed a whimsical line of animal sculpture for the gift industry. Today she works with copper and other metals to fabricate kinetic outdoor sculptures, among other forms of art. 
This show will close Nov. 23. The Sanctuary Gallery is open Mondays through Thursdays from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Fridays from 8:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. or by appointment — call 594-8656.
